et: probably borrowed from French {it}confessional{/it} (short for {it}chaire confessionale, siège confessional,{/it} literally, "confessional seat"), noun derivative of {it}confessional,{/it} adjective, "constituting or used for a confession," borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}confessiōnālis,{/it} from Latin {it}confessiōn-, confessiō{/it} {et_link|confession|confession} + {it}-ālis{/it} {et_link|-al:1|-al:1}
shortdef: a place where a priest hears confessions
the practice of confessing to a priest

dt: {bc}of, relating to, or being a {a_link|confession} especially of faith

dt.t: We live in a {wi}confessional{/wi} culture, provoked by social media and the internet and the warmth of the human impulse to share and … commiserate.

et: borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}confessiōnālis{/it} "constituting or used for a confession" {ma}{mat|confessional:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: of, relating to, or being a confession especially of faith
characterized by unguarded openness or self-revelation
